page.title: 08LOCAL HISTORY 2
page.content: The earliest remains of ancient man to be found at Stourmouth were discovered in 1960 when a trench was cut for a water main. Flint tools and pottery dating from the{Neolithic}period came to light. In 1965 a{hoard}of 49 objects buried by someone in the late{ {Bronze Age}where found, there were axes, socketed chisels and fragments of sword blades. The oldest part of the Church at Stourmouth is thought to be late Saxon, and built about 1000 AD. In the church is a monumental brass to a Rector Master Thomas Mareys buried in 1492. There are many wills on record to show that Stourmouth was a prosperous place in Medieval times with well to do Yeoman Farmers. Some of the same names appear again on the Georgian headstone in the churchyard.
